title: How to Make a Mini Pudding Pie Party Bar

steps.headline: Use cookies as toppings.
steps.description:
Leave them whole or crush them in a zipped plastic bag using a rolling pin. Some suggestions are:
Oreo cookies
Nilla wafers

Animal crackers, regular or frosted

steps.headline: Choose strawberries and bananas.
steps.description: These gives pies a nutritious treat; be sure to cut the fruit at the last minute or spritz them with lemon juice to avoid discoloration.

parts.name: Preparing the Puddings and Pie Crusts

steps.headline: Choose the kinds of pie crusts.
steps.description: Many supermarkets offer mini ready-to-make graham pie crusts. Make your own crusts using a mini muffin tin. Use your favorite recipe or refrigerated pie dough, although you may need to adjust the bake time and temperature.

steps.headline: Prepare the puddings.
steps.description: Choose at least two or three instant pudding flavors for variety, such as vanilla, chocolate, and banana. Most to all instant pudding boxes asks for two cups of milk per box mix.

steps.headline: Allow the pudding to set thoroughly.
steps.description: Puddings can be made the night before and left in the refrigerator until they are ready to be served.

steps.headline: Choose a table.
steps.description: Depending how many items you are planning to serve, tables can vary between a small fold-up table to a long serving table.

steps.headline: Keep foods at the proper temperature.
steps.description: Non-perishable food can easily be added into the desired bowls or platters and wrapped as is. Cold items should always be kept in the refrigerator until they are ready to be served. Avoid cutting fruit in advance, as certain foods such as bananas discolor fast. Fill a bucket up with ice and add cups of food in there to keep it cold.

steps.headline: Prop the items on different serving platters.

This will give off a delightful presentation. Some ideas include:

Cake stands
Fruit trays
Mason jars

steps.headline: Allow utensils for each item to be served.
steps.description: Insert spoons or tongs in each bowl or platter.

steps.headline: Group similar ingredients together.
steps.description: This is basically a uniformed guideline in most buffets. Have the items go in a line to how they are created - pie crusts first, puddings next, toppings after, and utensils last. Insert labeled sticks to each platter so your guests can know what the item is.

text:
Preparing the Toppings Use cookies as toppings. Leave them whole or crush them in a zipped plastic bag using a rolling pin. Some suggestions are:
Oreo cookies
Nilla wafers

Animal crackers, regular or frosted Choose strawberries and bananas. These gives pies a nutritious treat; be sure to cut the fruit at the last minute or spritz them with lemon juice to avoid discoloration. Provide the ultimate finishers - rainbow sprinkles and whipped cream.  Preparing the Puddings and Pie Crusts Choose the kinds of pie crusts. Many supermarkets offer mini ready-to-make graham pie crusts. Make your own crusts using a mini muffin tin. Use your favorite recipe or refrigerated pie dough, although you may need to adjust the bake time and temperature. Prepare the puddings. Choose at least two or three instant pudding flavors for variety, such as vanilla, chocolate, and banana. Most to all instant pudding boxes asks for two cups of milk per box mix. Allow the pudding to set thoroughly. Puddings can be made the night before and left in the refrigerator until they are ready to be served. Setting Up the Bar Choose a table. Depending how many items you are planning to serve, tables can vary between a small fold-up table to a long serving table. Keep foods at the proper temperature. Non-perishable food can easily be added into the desired bowls or platters and wrapped as is. Cold items should always be kept in the refrigerator until they are ready to be served. Avoid cutting fruit in advance, as certain foods such as bananas discolor fast. Fill a bucket up with ice and add cups of food in there to keep it cold. Prop the items on different serving platters. This will give off a delightful presentation. Some ideas include:
Lazy Susan
Cake stands
Fruit trays
Mason jars Allow utensils for each item to be served. Insert spoons or tongs in each bowl or platter. Group similar ingredients together. This is basically a uniformed guideline in most buffets. Have the items go in a line to how they are created - pie crusts first, puddings next, toppings after, and utensils last. Insert labeled sticks to each platter so your guests can know what the item is. Enjoy your party bar!
